Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2010 05:09PM JacquiAL wrote: I'm very interested in the connection between breast cancer and stress.  I've spent a fair amount of time on the Internet trying to find information.  What I've found is that stress and disease are being studied scientifically under the term Psychoneuroimmunology.  Here is a site to the definition with some links:  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychoneuroimmunology. I hope this is of some interest. Jacqui

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2010 05:11PM - edited Aug 16, 2010 08:34PM by JacquiAL Hi Aussieched, I took the Oncotype Test (two postive nodes) and my score was 17.  My oncologist said the chemo could be slightly detrimental to me so I choose not to do it.  I'm comfortable with the decision. I'm sorry you are having so many side effects from Femara.  Have you thought of trying another AI or Tamoxifen?  I am postmenapausal and tried Femara but couldn't tolerate the side effects.  My onc switched me to Tamoxifen.  I was doing pretty well on it but now have insomnia so he may switch me again if we can't get the insomnia under control.  If your onc doesn't feel you should switch have you thought about talking to him about an antidepressant? I hope others with postives nodes that have not had chemo will post.  I do think there are many of us. My best to you. Jacqui
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2010 11:10PM - edited Aug 16, 2010 11:14PM by JacquiAL DesignerMom, I appreciate the information about the Tailor Trial but couldn't find any indication that they are changing the way the Oncotype scores are interpreted now.  I think the Tailor Trial is arbitrarily placing certain scores in certain categories for purposes of the trial.  We don't know what the trial will determine and it is possible that some of those in the now intermediate risk range (18 - 31) could be determined to be in the low risk range once the results of the trial are known. As far as I know the following from Breastcancer.org is still the standard used to determine whether or not chemo is given using the Oncotype Test:Interpreting the results: When the Oncotype DX test is complete, your doctor will receive a report that includes your Recurrence Score. You and your doctor can use the following ranges to interpret your results: I do think it is a very personal decision whether or not to have chemo and each person has to decide for themselves based on whether information they have at the time. I'm glad your chemo is going well. My best to you. Jacqui
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: JacquiAL wrote: Hi, I was recently diagnosed with mild lymphedema. Since then I have gotten a minor rash on my forearm about 4 or 5 times. It usually only lasts a day or so but then will come back in few days or a week. I've been putting Cortaid on it and it seems to help but am wondering what is causing it.  I crochet and wonder if it could be my arm rubbing against the yarn.  I also volunteer with Friends of the Library and wonder if it could be contact with something on some of the donated books.  It's not painful.  I wore my sleeve day for the second time today and when I took it off I had the rash but don't think it's that because I've have it happen before I starting wearing the sleeve. Thanks in advance.  Jacqui  Dx 6/19/2009, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 2/22 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Rash on Lymphedema Forearm JacquiAL JacquiAL

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2010 01:26PM JacquiAL wrote: Hi Binney, Thanks for responding. Yes, it is frustrating when something like this pops up.  Today the rash is almost gone. My arm was blotchy and red but no bumps. I did see a therapist and she said I didn't need to use bandages but that I should wear the sleeve all day every day.  I will watch for any sign of infection. Thanks again Jacqui
